# Excluding Columns

ğŸ“– Review: Subsetting template: `object[ ROWS , COLS ]`

Type the following code in a new code chunk and run.

```{r , eval=FALSE}
no_cat <- mtcars[ , -c(8, 9)]   
head(no_cat)
```

ğŸ§ NOTICE that the row names (car models) and remaining columns are untouched.

ğŸ‘‰ Up Next! Logical operators: the key to subsetting data frames.

| Operator | Meaning |
| -------- | ------- |
| `&`      |  and    | 
| `|`      |  or     |
| `%in%`   | in set  |
| `!`      | not     |
| `==`     | equal to |
| `!=`     | not equal to|
| `>`      |greater than|
| `<`      |less than|
| `>=`     |greater *or* equal|
| `<=`     |less *or* equal   |

# Equality and Inequality

`==` asks â€œis exactly equal to?â€   

`!=` asks â€œis NOT equal to?â€.

Both return a logical vector.

```{r , eval=FALSE}
mtcars$cyl == 6        # â¡ TRUE where cylinders equal 6
mtcars$gear != 4       # â¡ TRUE where gears are NOT 4
```

ğŸ‘€ Checkâ€‘in: How many cars in the dataset have `mpg â‰¤ 15?`

```{r , eval=FALSE}
sum(mtcars$mpg <= 15)
```

ğŸš€ Explore and Play: ğŸ¤” Create your own questions based on the available data in `mtcars` *then* ğŸ“ Write the script to answer those questions. Create a memo note, demonstrate learning skill(s) used.

Other applications: ğŸ‘‰ Using these `TRUE`/`FALSE` results inside `[ ]` keeps only rows that satisfy the test.

```{r , eval=FALSE}
# Example 1: cars with exactly 6 cylinders
six_cyl <- mtcars[mtcars$cyl == 6, ]
head(six_cyl)
```

```{r , eval=FALSE}
# Example 2: cars with average mile per gallon over 22.
high_mpg <- mtcars[mtcars$mpg > 22, ]
# Verify
unique(high_mpg$mpg)
```

ğŸ¤” Remember how negative column indices work?

```{r, eval=FALSE}
selection <- mtcars[mtcars$hp >= 100, -c(3, 5, 8:9)]
head(selection)
```

"`-c(3,5,8:9)`" drops columns 3, 5, 8, 9. This keeps other variables.


# `which()`: From Logical to Position

`which()` converts `TRUE` positions to row indices (numbers). This avoids errors when `NA` is present and is handy for reâ€‘use.

```{r , eval=FALSE}
rows_fast <- which(mtcars$qsec < 16)  # quarterâ€‘mile < 16 sec
mtcars[rows_fast, c("mpg", "qsec")]  # inspect subset
```

# Combining Conditions

## And `&`

ğŸ¯ Goal: automatic (`am == 0`) *and* average miles per gallon is less than or equal to 22.

Type the following code in a new code chunk and run.

```{r , eval=FALSE}
auto_efficient <- mtcars[mtcars$am == 0 & mtcars$mpg >= 22, ]
auto_efficient
```

ğŸ§© Explanation: both tests must be TRUE for a row to survive.

## Or `|`

ğŸ¯ Goal: cars with 4 *or* 8 cylinders.

Type the following code in a new code chunk and run.

```{r , eval=FALSE}
four_or_eight <- mtcars[mtcars$cyl == 4 | mtcars$cyl == 8, ]
```

âš ï¸ Common Pain Point: using `|` where you meant `&` (or viceâ€‘versa). Think in words first: "I want rows that are both A **and** B" ğŸ‘‰ use `&`. "I want rows that are either A **or** B" ğŸ‘‰ use `|`.

## Membership `%in%`

Same task as above but scalable.

```{r , eval=FALSE}
four_or_eight_2 <- mtcars[mtcars$cyl %in% c(4, 8), ]
```

âš–ï¸ Compare `nrow(four_or_eight)` to `nrow(four_or_eight_2)`.

```{r , eval=FALSE}
nrow(four_or_eight) == nrow(four_or_eight_2) 
```

ğŸ” Look deeper: How are `|` and `%n%` similar and different from each other? ğŸ“ Create a memo note, demonstrate learning skill(s) used.

## Putting It All Together

ğŸš— Scenario: Pick cars that weigh < 3,000 lb, have hourse power between 110 and 180, and cylinders {4,6}.

```{r , eval=FALSE}
light_midpower <- mtcars[mtcars$wt < 3 &           
                           mtcars$hp >= 110 & mtcars$hp <= 180 &
                           mtcars$cyl %in% c(4, 6), ]
light_midpower
```
